newsitem.title: UK: No immediate Goldman comment on Sumitomo report.
newsitem.headline: No immediate Goldman comment on Sumitomo report.

text.p: Goldman Sachs International said it had no immediate comment on a British newspaper report that Sumitomo Corp had assigned the US investment bank the the task of unwinding huge holdings of copper.

"There is no comment we can make at the moment," said a London spokesperson at Goldman Sachs International, a subsidiary of Goldman Sachs Group. Sumitomo said in June it had lost $1.8 billion - later raised to $2.6 billion - on what it alleges was unauthorised trading by Yasuo Hamanaka. The trader built a big long position in copper.

The Guardian said on Monday that Goldman was in June handed perhaps the most sensitive job in the history of metals trading -- disposing of the copper holding. It quoted sources with a close knowledge of Sumitomo's position as saying that Goldman had completely unwound the stockpile although it added that other traders disagreed.
The Guardian said there was no suggestion of impropriety on Goldman's part but that the assignment "seems to have led" it into conflict with regulatory and police agencies.

They are investigating the Hamanaka affair. The Guardian said they might now regard Goldman as a source of information whilst it had had to instruct lawyers in relation to business carried out by its commodity dealing arm J. Aron and Co.
